cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/about.title: About DB Sync
cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/about.description: Cardano DB Sync is one of the core Cardano components, which provides a convenient way to find and query historical information from the Cardano blockchain through the use of a Structured Query Language (SQL) relational database. Db Sync connects to the local node as a client and synchronizes with the on-chain activity.

cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/best-.title: DB Sync best practices
cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/best-.description: This section outlines some best practices for using the Cardano DB Sync component.

cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/db-sy.title: DB Sync components
cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/db-sy.description: Cardano-db-sync consists of a set of components:

cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/db-sy.title: DB Sync set-up
cardano-components/cardano-db-sync/db-sy.description: Before you start working with a DB Sync, it is important that you have your Cardano node, DB Sync, and PostgreSQL installed on the same machine.

cardano-components/cardano-graphql.title: Cardano GraphQL
cardano-components/cardano-graphql.description: Cardano GraphQL is cross-platform, typed, and queryable API for Cardano. It provides a query interface to all the blockchain data via GraphQL, which is a convenient choice for client applications based on web technologies (applications written in JavaScript, or any other browser-based languages, for example) that use HTTP/REST APIs to talk to other services.

cardano-components/cardano-ledger-specs.title: Cardano ledger specs
cardano-components/cardano-ledger-specs.description: The Cardano ledger specifications component contains the formal specifications, executable models, and implementations of the Cardano ledger.

cardano-components/cardano-node.title: Cardano node
cardano-components/cardano-node.description: The cardano-node is the top-level repository for the node, which also aggregates components from other packages: consensus, ledger and networking, configurations, CLI, and logging and monitoring. The node no longer incorporates wallet or explorer functionality. The wallet backend and explorer backend are separate components that run in separate external processes that communicate with the node via local IPC.

cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/about.title: About Cardano Rosetta
cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/about.description: Cardano Rosetta is a specification and a set of tools that simplify the process of integrating with Cardano. The goal of Rosetta is to make the integration process easier, faster, and more reliable so that you can build once and integrate your blockchain everywhere.

cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/api-c.title: API calls
cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/api-c.description: This section outlines the available Rosetta API calls:

cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/get-s.title: Getting started with Rosetta
cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/get-s.description: The Rosetta API is made up of two core components; the Data API and the Construction API. Together, these APIs allow you to read and write to blockchains in a common format over a standard communication protocol. The specifications for these APIs can be found in the rosetta-specifications repository.

cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/learn.title: Learn
cardano-components/cardano-rosetta/learn.description: Rosetta is an open source specification and set of tools that help you to integrate with blockchains. Serving as a general-purpose integration framework, Rosetta provides a high-level interface that can be customized to work with any chain. The goal of Rosetta is to make the integration process easier, faster, and more reliable so that you can build once and integrate your blockchain everywhere.

cardano-components/cardano-rtview.title: Cardano RTView
cardano-components/cardano-rtview.description: RTView is a real-time monitoring program that provides visibility on the state of running Cardano nodes. It supports multiple node monitoring, even if the nodes work on different machines.

cardano-components/cardano-serialization.title: Cardano serialization library
cardano-components/cardano-serialization.description: This is a library for serialization and deserialization of data structures used in Cardano’s Haskell implementation of Shelley along with useful utility functions.

cardano-components/cardano-wallet.title: Cardano wallet
cardano-components/cardano-wallet.description: The Cardano wallet component provides an HTTP application programming interface (API) and command-line interface (CLI) for working with the wallet. It can be used as a component of a frontend such as Daedalus, which provides a friendly user interface for wallets.

cardano-components/ouroboros-network.title: Ouroboros network
cardano-components/ouroboros-network.description: The Ouroboros network component provides the API and documentation describing various levels of the networking layer of the Cardano Shelley implementation.

cardano-components/smash.title: SMASH
cardano-components/smash.description: SMASH is a metadata aggregation server that manages metadata for stake pools. The functionality provided by SMASH supports stake pool operations and the delegation ecosystem with its standardized framework for listing valid stake pools with verified metadata.

cardano-sidechains/getting-started/block.title: About block explorer
cardano-sidechains/getting-started/block.description: A block explorer allows you to inspect a blockchain to see its blocks and

cardano-sidechains/getting-started/intro.title: Introduction to sidechains
cardano-sidechains/getting-started/intro.description: A sidechain is simply a blockchain that depends on its main chain and is connected to it. This configuration allows the sidechain to have its own consensus algorithm and features. The sidechain is connected to the main chain through a two-way peg that allows the moving of assets between the chains. The finality of blocks is determined through a consensus mechanism that relies on the security of the main chain.

cardano-sidechains/getting-started/ourob.title: About Ouroboros BFT
cardano-sidechains/getting-started/ourob.description: Ouroboros BFT is a simple Byzantine fault tolerant consensus protocol. Named after the symbol of infinity, Ouroboros is the backbone of the Cardano ecosystem. Ouroboros BFT is the version that is implemented in Cardano's proof of concept EVM sidechain. It is a simple, deterministic protocol for ledger consensus that tolerates Byzantine faults.

cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.title: Set up development environment
cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.description: The EVM sidechain testnet is EVM-compatible with most Ethereum software to develop and deploy smart contracts including:

cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.title: Solidity resources
cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.description: Solidity is a statically-typed curly-braces programming language designed for developing smart contracts that run on Ethereum. Because its syntax is similar to ECMAScript, it will be familiar to many developers. There are significant differences, including:

cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.title: Use block explorer to verify a contract
Working with MetaMask
cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.description: The team has tested MetaMask compatibility with the sidechain using Google Chrome and Brave web browsers.

cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.title: Transferring tokens
cardano-sidechains/proof-of-concept-evm-.description: This tutorial will show you how to transfer SC_Tokens between the main chain and a sidechain.

cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/cha.title: Chain follower
cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/cha.description: A chain follower such as DB Sync is a component that observes the transactions on the main chain such as Cardano. The chain follower provides the information for a sidechain to stay consistent with the main chain.

cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/com.title: Committee rotation
cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/com.description: A sidechain is initialized by an SPO, or 'chain creator' who publishes the sidechain Plutus contract implementations including committee registration scripts. These registration scripts allow other SPOs to register or de-register as a candidate in the committee. The SPO also runs a sidechain validator node which starts the sidechain when a quorum of validators is reached.

cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/mai.title: Main chain Plutus scripts
cardano-sidechains/sidechain-toolkit/mai.description: The main chain utilizes the following components to handle interactions with a sidechain:

cardano-sidechains/support/getting-suppo.title: Getting support
cardano-sidechains/support/getting-suppo.description: Your feedback is important because it helps us improve Cardano.

cardano-sidechains/support/sidechain-faq.title: Sidechains FAQ
cardano-sidechains/support/sidechain-faq.description: This page answers some frequent questions for the Cardano Sidechains Toolkit and

cardano-testnet/about/secp.title: Valentine (SECP) upgrade
cardano-testnet/about/secp.description: The Valentine (or SECP) upgrade is Cardano’s intra-era hard fork that follows the Vasil upgrade. Valentine is a small and focused semantic change to the ledger, which brings new built-in functions to Plutus to support SECP elliptic curves (ECDSA and Schnorr). Although an intra-era hard fork requires a hard fork combinator event, it does not change the ledger era, which means that this is an upgrade to the Babbage era (Vasil functionality).

cardano-testnet/about/testnet-introducti.title: Vasil introduction
cardano-testnet/about/testnet-introducti.description: Note: New dedicated preview and pre-production environments have been recently spun up for the final stages of testing Vasil functionality. These environments offer improved chain density and a better developer experience.

cardano-testnet/daedalus-testnet.title: Daedalus wallet for the Cardano testnets
cardano-testnet/daedalus-testnet.description: Here you can download any of the special testnet-only versions of the Daedalus

cardano-testnet/getting-started.title: Getting started with Cardano testnets
cardano-testnet/getting-started.description: Note that the Cardano testnet is no longer recommended for testing purposes. The community is encouraged to use preview and pre-production testnet environments explained below.

cardano-testnet/local-testnet.title: Creating a local testnet
cardano-testnet/local-testnet.description: A local testnet enables developers and projects building on Cardano to test new features or functionality prior to deployment on global testnet environments. While preview and pre-production environments benefit the wider developer community, a local testnet allows the execution of a hard fork in your own setup and subsequent testing of DApp behavior.

cardano-testnet/overview.title: Overview
cardano-testnet/overview.description: Cardano testnets sit at the vanguard of network development, providing sandboxed environments for continuing innovation, harnessing the power of the Cardano community to iterate and improve.

cardano-testnet/tools/faucet.title: Testnets faucet
cardano-testnet/tools/faucet.description: Since the Cardano testnet is an independent network, separate from the Cardano

cardano-testnet/tools/staking-calculator.description: Staking calculator is a tool used to predict approximate rewards a user may

development-guidelines/cardano-node-cour.title: The Cardano node video course
development-guidelines/cardano-node-cour.description: The IOG Academy provides this course on YouTube.

development-guidelines/node-monitoring.title: Logging and monitoring
development-guidelines/node-monitoring.description: Regular monitoring of active nodes is crucial to determine if the node is running optimally, if the system is performant, or if fine-tuning is required.

development-guidelines/node-tests.title: Cardano node tests
development-guidelines/node-tests.description: Cardano node tests are CLI-based system and end-to-end tests for the Cardano node.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Introduction
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: A transaction is an event created, signed, and sent by a user to modify the ledger's state. It is commonly used to transfer ada or other tokens from one user to another. Additionally, it can serve various purposes, such as token creation, delegation registration to a stake pool, or interaction with smart contracts, among others. The process to modify the ledger through a transaction is as follows:

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Minting transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: The ability to create and manage custom tokens is one of the distinguishing features of the Cardano blockchain. Minting refers to the process of 'producing new tokens, either as part of an initial coin offering (ICO) or ongoing token issuance'. Minting transactions enable users to generate or burn tokens according to predefined rules. This tutorial explores the details of minting transactions on Cardano.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Multiple purposes
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: Cardano allows more complex transactions. So far you've seen various types of transactions: simple script, minting, staking, delegating, etc. But Cardano provides the flexibility to create more complex transactions and mix all the types of transactions needed. For example, adding metadata to minting transactions, or adding a staking component to a simple script transaction. This tutorial shows how to send a transaction with multiple purposes.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Redelegation
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: This tutorial will show how to redelegate your stake to another stake pool. There can be multiple reasons to redelegate your stake, but the most common ones are:

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Staking transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: Staking is a fundamental feature of Cardano, allowing you to earn rewards by delegating ada to stake pools. This tutorial shows how to delegate your ada to a stake pool, withdraw rewards, or stop delegating your ada if you decide to switch to another stake pool.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Withdrawing transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: This part of the tutorial will demonstrate how easy it is to claim rewards using the cardano-cli. First, you need to ensure that you already have rewards available in your stake address. Check it with the following command:

explore-cardano/eras-and-phases.description: This overview is based on CIP-59.

explore-cardano/fee-structure.description: Cardano uses a transaction fee system that covers the processing and long-term

explore-cardano/monetary-policy.description: Cardano aims to achieve true decentralization with the introduction of

explore-cardano/parameter-guide.title: Cardano protocol parameters reference guide
explore-cardano/parameter-guide.description: Protocol parameters on Cardano are the various settings that define the blockchain's behavior. Some protocol parameters are stable and non-updatable while others can be adjusted to adapt to changing conditions over time.

explore-cardano/relevant-research-papers.title: Relevant research papers and specifications
explore-cardano/relevant-research-papers.description: Cardano is a third-generation blockchain platform that aims to provide the

explore-cardano/time.title: Time handling on Cardano
explore-cardano/time.description: Time is necessarily relative to every participant in the blockchain system and is critically important to support and maintain the safety properties of the Ouroboros consensus protocol. Minted blocks are expected to be propagated to all nodes in the system in a timely manner, so time requires the construction of a globally acceptable representation for consensus to be reached.

learn/about-hard-forks.description: The term hard fork describes a radical change in the blockchain: a change from

learn/cardano-addresses.title: Cardano addresses
learn/cardano-addresses.description: The addresses are a blake2b-256 hash of the relevant verifying/public keys concatenated with some metadata that can be stored on the Cardano blockchain.

learn/cardano-keys.title: Cardano keys
learn/cardano-keys.description: Keys are asymmetric cryptography key pairs used for:

learn/cardano-node.title: Cardano nodes
learn/cardano-node.description: The Cardano node is the top-level component within the network. Network nodes connect to each other within the networking layer, which is the driving force

learn/consensus-explained.title: Consensus explained
learn/consensus-explained.description: Consensus is the process of reaching a majority opinion by everyone involved in running the blockchain. An agreement must be made on which blocks to produce, which chain to adopt and to determine the single state of the network. The consensus protocol determines how individual nodes assess the current state of the ledger system and reach a consensus.

learn/stake-pools.title: Stake pools
learn/stake-pools.description: A stake pool is a reliable server node that focuses on ledger maintenance and holds the combined resources  -the 'stake'- of various stakeholders in a single entity. Stake pools are responsible for processing transactions that will be placed in the ledger, as well as producing new blocks. Stake pools are at the core of Ouroboros, Cardano's proof-of-stake protocol.

new-to-cardano/what-is-a-smart-contract.title: What is a smart contract?
new-to-cardano/what-is-a-smart-contract.description: Smart contracts on Cardano are simple programs often referred to as validator scripts in which users define custom logic. They are automatically executed by each Cardano node validating the transaction when the transaction attempts to move funds from the script's address. The address of each script is derived from the hash-sum of the compiled script.
